awd_titl_txt: Getting Through the Gateway: Can Corequisite Algebra Improve STEM Progress and Degree Attainment at Community and Technical Colleges?
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by broadening participation and institutional capacity for STEM learning at community and technical colleges. According to mathematics placement tests, the majority of beginning students arrive at public two-year colleges under-prepared for college-level mathematics.  College-level mathematics is an essential milestone for entering STEM fields and, unfortunately, many students never complete their first college-level math course. The traditional pathway for students who are not ready for college-level math is a sequence of developmental math courses that students must complete before taking college-level math (e.g., Algebra); the developmental courses do not usually receive credit towards a college degree.  Corequisite algebra  pairs credit-bearing college algebra with a developmental-education support course, with the potential to allow students to more quickly pass their first college-level mathematics course in the STEM sequence.  Using Texas state administrative data, this project will examine whether taking corequisite algebra, as opposed to the traditional developmental math sequence, influences the STEM pipeline at community and technical colleges. The goals of the study are to: 1) Estimate the extent to which students who enroll in corequisite math courses are more likely to complete STEM courses and to obtain a certificate or degree than students in traditional developmental education programs; 2) Test which corequisite models offer the largest and smallest improvement in student outcomes, using measures of course design; 3) Examine whether students from various backgrounds (race, gender, socioeconomic status) benefit more or less from corequisite mathematics and illuminate the processes that students follow after success and failure in their corequisite course.

To examine the effects of corequisite algebra course enrollment on students' educational outcomes in STEM fields, this project will apply quantitative research methods to Texas state administrative data and course-level information from corequisite courses. The PI will use two complementary methods that strengthen the possibility of making causal inferences about the impact of corequisite algebra on various STEM milestones: regression discontinuity design and difference-in-differences. To adjust for pre-treatment characteristics, the project will use placement cutoff scores and variation in course offerings across colleges  to support a rigorous research design. The study will examine the varied effects of corequisite algebra across race, gender, and family income, and study which corequisite models are most effective and for which students. Community colleges and technical colleges educate the majorities of Black, Hispanic, and low-income students in the American higher education system. The study will offer evidence about how corequisite algebra courses impact key outcomes in STEM pathways (Goal 1), which corequisite models are most and least effective and for which students (Goal 2), and whether those effects vary across subgroups (Goal 3). The results will offer practical findings that colleges in Texas and across the country can use as they develop additional corequisite math coursework and seek to improve their output of students in STEM fields. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Colleges and states across the country are seeking to make changes to how they teach students deemed academically underprepared for college math. Through the project, “Getting Through the Gateway: Can Corequisite Algebra Improve STEM Progress and Degree Attainment at Community and Technical Colleges?,” Lauren Schudde (PI) examined the outcomes of students who enrolled in corequisite math coursework, in which students concurrently enroll in college math and paired developmental support courses within the same term. Using Texas state administrative data, the project examined whether taking corequisite algebra, as opposed to the traditional developmental math sequence, influences the STEM pipeline at community and technical colleges, while also exploring variation in the implementation of corequisites at public two-year colleges and variation in the effects across student demographics.

 

Results from the project illustrate that:

1)     Corequisite math coursework improves a variety of community college student outcomes, on average, with positive short- and long-term outcomes, including increased college-level math course completion, STEM major selection, and vertical transfer to a four-year institution.

2)     There appears to be limited variation in the effects of corequisite math across race and socioeconomic status, with minimal consistent differences in the patterns of effects across subgroups.

3)     Colleges in Texas, where corequisite coursework is now mandated for students who are assessed as underprepared for college, varied in how they implemented corequisite math courses. Some of those varied corequisite course structures—e.g., using mid-ability classrooms or using the same instructor for the college-level and paired support courses—improve student outcomes.

Overall, the project offers evidence that states and colleges can use to inform subsequent policy decisions and instructional design. 

 

Intellectual Merit

 The project is one of the first to use causal methods to estimate the effect of enrollment in corequisite math, compared with traditional prerequisite developmental education, on several outcomes, including math course completion, persistence, STEM major selection, and degree attainment. Findings from Meiselman & Schudde (2022) indicate that enrolling in corequisite math, rather than in prerequisite dev-ed math, improves completion of the gateway math requirement and increases the number of math courses completed in the first year. Within 3 years, students who start in corequisite math are 7 percentage points more likely to select a STEM major (given that only about 10% of students in the sample entered college in STEM, this increase is quite large). The second article from the grant, Ryu et al. (2022) illustrates that the manner in which colleges implement the corequisite support course (e.g., whether it has the same instructor as the college-level course; faculty type; contact hours) shapes student success in the college-level math course.

Broader Impacts

The project informs broad policy discussions, as well as corequisite model development, by showing the average effects of corequisite reforms and illuminating which corequisite math course design structures most improve outcomes and which students benefit the most from corequisite math. Ryu, Schudde, and Pack-Cosme (2022) identified institutional variation in the way colleges implemented corequisite coursework following a state mandate in Texas. The results offer colleges working to implement corequisite math reforms evidence that can shape their practices. The project also examined variation in the effects of corequisite math coursework across students’ demographic backgrounds, finding that most students—at least across race and socioeconomic status—experienced similar benefits from enrolling in corequisite math. Taken together, the overall project suggest that providing students access to corequisite math (compared with prerequisite developmental math)—and ensuring that access is equal across student subgroups—should improve access to STEM pathways through two-year colleges. Increased access to corequisite coursework math—which enables students to more efficiently enter and pass college-level math—appears more important than how those reforms are implemented (i.e., varied program designs for corequisites) when it comes to improving student outcomes.

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2023
Modified by: Lauren Schudde
